Detailed Description

The String class represents character strings.

All strings used in LibSylph are instances of this class.

Strings are constant, their value can not be changed after they are created. StringBuffer implements a mutable string. The copy constructor only copies a pointer to the actual internal data, making Strings trivial to copy, they should therefore be treated as built-in types, such as ints and floats.

The class String includes methods for examining individual characters of the sequence, for comparing strings, for searching strings, for extracting substrings, and for creating a copy of a string with all characters translated to uppercase or to lowercase. Case mapping relies heavily on the information provided by the Unicode Consortium's Unicode 5.1 specification. The specification's UnicodeData.txt and SpecialCasing.txt files are used extensively to provide case mapping. For specific details, please refer to the ICU library documentation.

Strings are encoded internally in UTF-16, but only the Basic Multilinguar Plane (up to U+FFFF) is supported. Future versions may add support for the other planes (up to U+10FFFF). In this case, UTF-32 will be used instead.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

Sylph::String::String (  ) 

Creates an empty String.

An empty String has a length of 0 and does not contain any internal data. All empty Strings are equal to each other.

Since Strings are immutable, the main use of this constructor is to compare against the empty string, or to supply a dummy value to a function.

Sylph::String::String ( const char *  orig  ) 

Creates a String from a C-style string.

The pointer passed must be a pointer to a null ('\0') terminated character array. The length of the character array is deduced from the place of the null character. Passing anything else than a null-terminated character array to this constructor may result in undefined behaviour.

The character array passed is expected to be encoded in UTF-8. Any other encodings, or invalid UTF-8, may result in Unicode replacement characters ('ï¿½', U+FFFD) to be inserted into the character sequence.

The characters in the original string will be converted to UTF-16. The original string will not be modified.

An example: 

String foo = "abc";
 String bar("def");
Parameters:
orig A c-style null terminated string encoded in UTF-8

Sylph::String::String ( const Array< uchar >  orig  ) 

Creates a String from an Array of uchars.

The Array passed must not be null ('\0') terminated. The length of the String will be equal to the length of the Array. The data in the Array passed is expected to be encoded in UTF-16. The data is copied into the String without any checks applied

The original Array will not be modified. Please note that for construction of a 'mutable' string, StringBuffer is prefered.

Parameters:
orig An Array containing the values to be copied into this string

Sylph::String::String ( const std::string &  orig  ) 

Creates a String from a std::string.

This constructor takes the same effect as if you would have used String(orig.c_str()) and is supplied for your convenience. The requirements are identical of to String::String(const char*). The original string will not be modified

Parameters:
orig A standard library string to convert to a String.

Sylph::String::String ( const String &  orig  ) 

Creates a String referring to the other String's data.

This constructor will not make a full copy of the data contained by the original string, instead, it will take a copy of the pointer pointing to the actual data. Afterwards, the two Strings will be both sharing the same data.

If you do want a 1:1 copy of a String, please look at the String::copy() function.

Parameters:
orig A string to share string data with.

Sylph::String::String ( const uchar  c  ) 

Creates a String from a single character.

The length of the String will be 1. The character is copied into the String.

Parameters:
c A character.

Sylph::String::String ( const bool  b  ) 

Converts a bool into a String.

If the specified boolean is true, then this String will be equal to "true", otherwise this String will be equal to "false". In other words, this constructor is equivalent to 

String s = b ? "true" : "false";
Parameters:
b A boolean.

Sylph::String::String ( const sint  i  ) 

Converts a 32-bit signed integer to a String.

The integer will be represented in base 10. If the integer is negative, an ASCII minus character ('-', U+002D) will be prepended to the value. If the value is not negative, no sign will be prepended. If integer is equal to 0, a single ASCII 0 will be used (U+0030). The String will match the regex (0|-?[1-9][0-9]+).

Parameters:
i A 32-bit signed integer.

Sylph::String::String ( const suint  i  ) 

Converts a 32-bit unsigned integer to a String.

The integer will be represented in base 10. If integer is equal to 0, a single ASCII 0 will be used (U+0030). The String will match the regex (0|[1-9][0-9]+).

Parameters:
i A 32-bit unsigned integer.

Sylph::String::String ( const slong  l  ) 

Converts a 64-bit signed integer to a String.

The integer will be represented in base 10. If the integer is negative, an ASCII minus character ('-', U+002D) will be prepended to the value. If the value is not negative, no sign will be prepended. If integer is equal to 0, a single ASCII 0 will be used (U+0030). The String will match the regex (0|-?[1-9][0-9]+).

Parameters:
l A 64-bit signed integer.

Sylph::String::String ( const sulong  l  ) 

Converts a 64-bit unsigned integer to a String.

The integer will be represented in base 10. If integer is equal to 0, a single ASCII 0 will be used (U+0030). The String will match the regex (0|[1-9][0-9]+).

Parameters:
l A 64-bit unsigned integer.

Sylph::String::String ( const float  f  ) 

Converts a floating point number to a String.

The float will be represented in base 10. The exact conversion method is mentioned below. All characters are encoded in pure ASCII.

  • If this floating point number represents NaN (not a number) according to the IEEE 754 floating point standard, in other words, if it is equal to the result of the division 0.0/0.0, it will convert to the literal string "NaN".
  • For all other values, a string composed of a sign character and a magnitude (absolute value) will be created. For a negative value, the minus sign ('-', U+002D) will be prepended. For a positive value, no sign will be prepended. The magnitude is composed as following:
    • If the magnitude is infinity, i.e. if it is the result of a division of any non-zero value by zero, the literal string "Infinity" will be produced. In case of a negative infinity (produced if either one of the operands, but not both, are negative), as per the above rule the literal string "-Infinity" will be produced.
    • If the magnitude is an integer, i.e. there is no decimal fraction, the actual conversion will be done by the integer conversion algorithm.
    • If the magnitude is greater than or equal to 10-3, but less than 107 then it is represented as the integer part in decimal form with no leading zeroes, followed by a dot ('.', U+002E), followed by up to 8 digits representing the fractional part. No trailing zeroes will be put in the resulting string.
    • If the magnitude is greater than or equal to 107, or less than 10-3, the number will be represented in scientific notation. It is composed of a single significant digit, followed by an optional decimal fraction and an exponent. The decimal fraction consists of a dot ('.', U+002E) and up to 8 significant digits without trailing zeroes. The exponent is of the form eN, where N is a integer, optionally with a minus sign for a negative exponent.

The resulting String will match the regex -?(Infinity|[0-9]*(\.[0-9]{7}[1-9])?(e-?[0-9]*)?) .

Parameters:
f A floating point number to a String.

Sylph::String::String ( const double  d  ) 

Converts a double-width floating point number to a String.

The double will be represented in base 10. The exact conversion method is mentioned below. All characters are encoded in pure ASCII.

  • If this floating point number represents NaN (not a number) according to the IEEE 754 floating point standard, in other words, if it is equal to the result of the division 0.0/0.0, it will convert to the literal string "NaN".
  • For all other values, a string composed of a sign character and a magnitude (absolute value) will be created. For a negative value, the minus sign ('-', U+002D) will be prepended. For a positive value, no sign will be prepended. The magnitude is composed as following:
    • If the magnitude is infinity, i.e. if it is the result of a division of any non-zero value by zero, the literal string "Infinity" will be produced. In case of a negative infinity (produced if either one of the operands, but not both, are negative), as per the above rule the literal string "-Infinity" will be produced.
    • If the magnitude is an integer, i.e. there is no decimal fraction, the actual conversion will be done by the integer conversion algorithm.
    • If the magnitude is greater than or equal to 10-3, but less than 107 then it is represented as the integer part in decimal form with no leading zeroes, followed by a dot ('.', U+002E), followed by up to 16 digits representing the fractional part. No trailing zeroes will be put in the resulting string.
    • If the magnitude is greater than or equal to 107, or less than 10-3, the number will be represented in scientific notation. It is composed of a single significant digit, followed by an optional decimal fraction and an exponent. The decimal fraction consists of a dot ('.', U+002E) and up to 16 significant digits without trailing zeroes. The exponent is of the form eN, where N is a integer, optionally with a minus sign for a negative exponent.

The resulting String will match the regex -?(Infinity|[0-9]*(\.[0-9]{15}[1-9])?(e-?[0-9]*)?) .

Parameters:
d A double-width floating point number.

Sylph::String::~String (  )  [virtual]

Default destructor.

If this String is sharing data with any other Strings, it will not release this data until no Strings refer to this data anymore.

Member Function Documentation

const char * Sylph::String::ascii (  )  const

Converts the String to ASCII.

The conversion algorithm goes as follows:

  • For every unicode character < U+007F, which can be represented in pure ASCII, the character is copied into the returned buffer
  • Every other character will be replaced by a question mark literal ('?', U+003F) in the returned buffer.
The returned buffer is null-terminated, and does not contain excess space. It is not managed by LibSylph, you need to delete it yourself. Future versions may change this behaviour, and manage the buffer with LibSylph's garbage collector.
Returns:
A c-style string with pure ASCII characters only.

const uchar Sylph::String::at ( std::size_t  idx  )  const

Returns the character at the specified index.

The index is 0-based and has a maximal value of length() - 1.

Exceptions:
ArrayException if idx > length() - 1.
Parameters:
idx the index of the character to return
Returns:
the character at the specified index, in UTF-16.

bool Sylph::String::equalsIgnoreCase ( const String  other  )  const

Compares two strings ignoring differencies in case.

This is the same as s.toLowerCase() == t.toLowerCase().

Parameters:
other A string to compare to
Returns:
true if both Strings are equal ignoring case, false otherwise.

sint Sylph::String::hashCode (  )  const [virtual]

Calculates an unique hash code for this object.

The returned value should be indentical for equal classes. It is possible to have the same hash code for non-equal classes, returning a constant number is a valid implementation of this function. However, the hash code is used for optimalisation in several collection classes, therefore, having this function return a generally unique hash code (such that x != y almost certainly guarantees x.hashCode() != y.hashCode() will make access times for those collection classes much faster.

Returns:
A generally unique hash value for this class.

Implements Sylph::Hashable.

sidx_t Sylph::String::indexOf ( const String  substr,
idx_t  start = 0 
) const

Returns the first index from given start index in this String on which the specified substring occurs.

The index is 0-based.

Parameters:

start The first index to start looking for.
Returns:
If the substring occurs in this String, then the index of the first character of that substring is returned, else -1 is returned.
Exceptions:
ArrayException if start >= length()

std::size_t Sylph::String::length (  )  const

Returns the length of this String.

The length is equal to the amount of UTF-16 characters in this String. Therefore, the returned value is 1-based.

Returns:
The amount of characters in this String.

Sylph::String::operator const char * (  )  const

Converts this String to a C-style array of chars.

This is equivalent to utf8(). This conversion operator allows for passing Strings to functions expecting C-style strings without explicit conversion.

Returns:
A C-style string according to utf8().

Sylph::String::operator std::string (  )  const

Converts this String to a Standard Library string.

This will effectively convert it to a C-style string encoded in UTF-8 and construct a std::string from that.

Returns:
A Standard Library string with the same contents as this String.

String Sylph::String::substring ( std::idx_t  begin,
std::idx_t  end 
) const

Returns a new String containing all characters from the given begin index up to and including the given end index.

The indices are 0-based. The length of the new String will be equal to end - begin - 1.

Parameters:
begin The first index of where to cut the substring.
end The last index to where to cut the substring.
Returns:
A string containing all characters from the given begin index to the given end index.
Exceptions:
ArrayException if begin >= length() || end >= length() || begin > end.

String Sylph::String::substring ( std::idx_t  begin  )  const

Returns a new String containing all characters from the given index to the end of the String.

The index is 0-based. The length of the new String will be equal to length() - begin - 1.

Parameters:
begin The first index of where to cut the substring.
Returns:
A string containing all characters from the given begin index.
Exceptions:
ArrayException if begin >= length().

String Sylph::String::toLowerCase (  )  const

Converts the String to lower case.

The exact contents of the lower case string are dependant on the characters and the locale used, the resulting string may be shorter or longer than the original.

Returns:
A lower case version of this String

String Sylph::String::toUpperCase (  )  const

Converts the String to upper case.

The exact contents of the upper case string are dependant on the characters and the locale used, the resulting string may be shorter or longer than the original.

Returns:
An upper case version of this String

String Sylph::String::trim (  )  const

Removes all whitespace characters on the front and on the end of the String.

Whitespace characters are defined in the array spacechars.

Returns:
The trimmed string.

const Array< uchar > Sylph::String::utf16 (  )  const

Returns an UTF-16 representation of this String.

Because String uses UTF-16 internally, it will simply return a copy of the internal buffer. The returned value is not null-terminated. The length of the returned Array is equal to the length of the String. You cannot use this Array to modify the interal buffer directly, for that would make data sharing impossible (as all Strings that share data would be modified). Instead, use a StringBuffer or an Array<uchar>.

Returns:
An Array<uchar> with the UTF-16 encoded String in it.

const char * Sylph::String::utf8 (  )  const

Converts the String to UTF-8.

This is the default conversion algorithm for implicit conversion to C string. Each UTF-16 character will be represented as its UTF-8 counterpart. The length of the returned buffer is in the best case (i.e. pure ASCII) length() + 1; in the worst case (i.e CJK or other high Unicode characters) it's 3 * length() + 1. The returned buffer is null-terminated, and does not contain excess space. It is not managed by LibSylph, you need to delete it yourself. Future versions may change this behaviour, and manage the buffer with LibSylph's garbage collector.

Returns:
A c-style Unicode string encoded in UTF-8.
